title: employment rate soars to record high as wages pace ahead of inflation
story: The number of people out of work dropped 46,000 to 1.42million, latest Office for National Statistics figures revealed yesterday.Employment is also at the highest since records began in 1971 with 75.6 per cent in a job.Numbers in work rose 179,000 to 32.34million, with 2,000 people finding work each day.The plunge in unemployment - to just 4.2 per cent - comes as the number of EU nationals working in the UK fell for the first time in eight years.In the three months to March there were around 2.29million EU workers — down 28,000 on the same period last year.The drop was fuelled by 91,000 workers leaving from eight Eastern European countries that joined the EU in 2004, such as Poland and Hungary.The net number of Brits employed rose 417,000 to a record 28.73million.Experts said it was too early to say if Brits were finding jobs due to fewer migrants. Pro-EU campaign groups warned of a Brexodus brain drain.But Alp Mehmet, of Migration Watch, said: “There are tentative signs that businesses may be turning to the domestic workforce.”Average earnings excluding bonuses also rose by 2.9 per cent — outstripping inflation.Chancellor Philip Hammond said: “Growth in real wages means people are starting to feel the benefit of more money in their pockets.”The Resolution think tank warned pay was still around £730 a year lower than a decade ago.But Gerard Lyons, chief economist at NetWealth, said the “great” job figures showed how wrong Remain campaigners had been with their warnings about how a Brexit vote would cripple the economy.He said: “Project Fear’s warnings look more ridiculous by the day.”Official figures yesterday showed the employment rate among 16 to 64-year-olds was 80 per cent for the first time since 1991.The Office for National Statistics said more blokes than ever were working beyond traditional retirement age, with 731,000 over-65s clocking on.A record 71.2 per cent of working age women have a job, the ONS added. It was as low as 60 per cent in the late Eighties.

title: uk weather forecast may bank holiday latest temperatures heatwave
story: A forecaster claims we could see highs of 30Cs near the end of the month - as the fine weather looks to make a return.Exacta Weather forecaster James Madden predicts summer could kick off with a sizzling few days.He told the Express: The remainder of this month will remain predominantly summery and confidence is increasing for another burst of very warm to hot temperatures for the next bank holiday weekend.“It is plausible that maximum temperatures could rise into the high 20Cs or even the low 30Cs for several days in a row within this period.This will pave the way for a warm and settled start to summer.”The Met Office predicts: Temperatures will probably be close to or just above average for late May, but there may be some marked daily variations with chilly nights, but also some cooler days under cloud and rain.The end of May, could well remain mostly dry and warm in the south and south east, with the potential for some very warm spells, which may also lead to brief periods of thundery rain.Many parts of the country have seen a sunny and warm day today, in what could be a taster of things to come.Temperatures could get up 25C today, beating usually sunnier spots such as Barcelona.Tomorrow should start cloudy but turn bright and dry for most of the UK - although the temperature is predicted to drop slightly.However from Thursday into the weekend Brits can expect plenty of fine weather and sunshine.Therefore the royal couple and the thousands of well-wishers who will gather in Windsor on Saturday can look forward to mostly clear skies, according to the Met Office.American Meghan will be relieved after her reported worries about Britain’s weather disrupting her wedding.Forecaster Bonnie Diamond said some puffs of light, fluffy cloud may form in the late morning and early afternoon as temperatures soar but not enough to completely block out the sun.She said: We are expecting it to be fine and dry. There could be a little bit of mist early on but that will burn off relatively quickly.The main uncertainty is cloud cover, with fair weather cloud developing through the afternoon - its temperature driven.At the moment the average temperature looks like 19C to 20C (68F) but up to 23C is possible.The amount of sunshine and cloud cover will determine whether we get those upper temperatures.Most of the UK is expected to share in the fine and dry weather but there is a chance of some rain as it become cloudier and breezier in far north-western parts.

title: ramadan 2018 drink water fasting hours rules
story: Muslims observing the holy month across the world will be expected to fast. Read on to find out how Ramadan is observed.Fasting is one of the five pillars of Islam, so all adult Muslims are expected to fast.Adult Muslims are also expected to read and reflect on the entire Koran, the holy book, while abstaining from smoking and sex.During daylight hours, you are not allowed to drink water.But the NHS does recommend adults to break their fast if they do become very hydrated.The NHS said: Poor hydration can be made worse by weather conditions and even everyday activities like walking to work or housework.If you produce very little or no urine, feel disoriented and confused or faint as a result of dehydration, you must stop fasting and have a drink of water or other fluid.If a fast is broken, it will need to be compensated for by fasting at a later date. Or they can pay fidyah, a religious term for donation of food or money.Muslim children are expected to begin fasting once they have reached puberty, usually by the age of 14.There is no national law that prevents young children or teens from fasting.The NHS does advise against children as young as seven or eight fasting.Advice from the national health body read: Its a good idea to make children aware of what fasting involves and to practice fasting for a few hours at a time.Ramadan shifts according to the movement of the moon.Muslims will be expected to abstain from food and drink between sunrise and sunset for 30 days.Usually adults will have a meal just before dawn, and another after sunset.At the end of the fast, when the sun has gone down, family and friends will get together for iftar to break their fast.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 180 social network rely five
story: Researchers who carried out a poll of 1,500 adults revealed partners are most likely to be in the circle of trust, along with parents and siblings.It also emerged we turn to the trusted inner circle for help or support at least twice a month.The study was commissioned by American Express to celebrate the launch of its new brand campaign and understand more about how the support of others can help propel you forward.Digital entrepreneur Jamal Edwards, who is working with American Express on the launch of its new campaign, said: “Having the support of others can be instrumental to success, but it’s not always about having friends in high places.Support can come from anywhere and more often than not it’s people you’ve known all your life.’’The study also found for nearly half of Brits (47 per cent) this social support network has become more important today than ever before.More than a third put this down to busier lives while 28 per cent blamed an increased pressure to succeed.According to the data, Brits believe having a support network around you is one of the most important factors to self-achievement.Additionally, the research identified the support network is primarily made up of a “backer” (64 per cent), a “comforter” (62 per cent) and a “cheerleader” (62 per cent).It also consists of a “constructive critic” (45 per cent) and a “big picture thinker” (40 per cent).Jamal Edwards, who is also the founder of SBTV, a British company run by a small team of young people working on web-based content, added:  “I’ve relied on my parents more than anyone else.“They’ve helped back me on many occasions and given me the encouragement to get to where I am today.“For example, they bought me my first camera for Christmas when I was 15 which is when I really got into making videos and I became inseparable from the camera.”

title: worlds best engagement photos 2018
story: The winning entries in the Junebug Weddings annual competition were chosen from almost 6,000 entries from 30 countries.The eyecatching images include couples walking under double rainbows, beneath galaxies of stars, kissing underwater, and even riding a dirt bike.The entries are anonymised before judges score them, making it easier to find the top 50.World-renowned wedding photographers Helena and Laurent, Don + Helen, and Kristen Marie Parker assisted the Junebug Weddings team in judging the contest.The final collection of shots is comprised of images that received the most points as well as ones that the Junebug team felt added diversity and representation to the collection.According to Carrie Schwab, editor-in-chief of Junebug Weddings, a good engagement photograph should showcase passion, joy, and just the overall excitement of being engaged to your partner.Each year the popular website hosts a number of photo competitions including Best of the Best Destination Contest and Best Wedding Photos.Carrie said: Nearly 6,000 images were submitted to this years engagement contest, which is actually the biggest number weve ever received for our engagement contest.”The engagement photo contest has run for the last six years, while Junebug has been running similar competitions for the last nine years.The aim of the engagement photo competition is to capture the multitude of emotions the couple are experiencing and to reflect that to the audience.

title: inside north koreas massive new holiday resort with three mile beach so would you go
story: They appear to show more than 170 structures being built along a three-mile stretch of beach on the Wonsan-Kalma peninsula.The pictures reveal the construction of everything from a pyramid-shaped hotel, luxury villas and even an artificial lake, according to experts at NK News.When the tourist area is built, it will satisfy the demand of domestic and foreign tourists, the state-run KCNA news agency said in a statement.It said the chosen location would be the ideal place to link various tourist destinations to the Wonsan international tourist zone.Now high-resolution photos from Skysat show the North Korean dictator is following through on his promise.Pictures from the ground show buildings tens of stories high, meaning the entire resort could house tens of thousands of people.Meanwhile time-lapse imagery suggests the work began almost immediately after Kims speech and has been carried out at a rapid pace.It shows temporary shelters and workers facilities springing up along the coast between January and February.Photos even show floodlights being erected all over the beach so construction can continue at night time.North Korean soldiers are often drafted in to work on such projects, according to NK news, which says the resort could be completed as early as March.With tourism one being one of the few industries not targeted by US sanctions, experts believe the resort is aimed at making money through tourism.Wonsan and Kalma airport are also important defence areas, used for large-scale artillery drills and as the launch site for dozens of missile tests in recent years.In April last year, Kim used the same beach near Wonsans new airport to unleash an artillery drill described by state media as the country’s largest ever.Last year, America banned its citizens from visiting North Korea and there are no up-to-date statistics on current visitors.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: women prefer long legged fellas because healthier and wealthier
story: Blokes with a bit extra below are expected to be healthier and wealthier.That suggests they will make a good mate, according to the researchers.But lanky men, such as beanpole striker Peter Crouch, are out of luck because the gangly look is associated with poor genes.The findings come from a study in which 341 women were shown computer generated images based on real men.They were asked to rate their attractiveness as the arms and legs were adjusted but their heights remained constant.Men scored highest when their legs, measured from hip to ankle, were a little bit longer than average.It means a man 5ft 9in tall (175cm) has an optimum leg length between 34.2inches (86.8cm) and 34.4inches (87.3cm), the Cambridge University researchers say.Longer legs are said to indicate high economic status, robustness and good nutrition.They may also be a sign of biomechanical efficiency when walking or running.Short legs, however, have been linked to diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure and dementia.The length of arms relative to the body made no difference to attraction. title: sajid javid reignites windrush 63 wrongly deported
story: In comments that stunned MPs, the Tory rising star said the Government was now desperately trying to get in contact with cases discovered from a trawl of 8,000 deportations over the past 15 years.It marked the first time a Minister has put a figure on wrongful removals since the debacle erupted last month.Caribbean citizens who came to Britain before 1973 should have been granted the right to remain in the UK indefinitely.But speaking to a cross-party Home Affairs Committee Mr Javid said there were 63 Windrush-era migrants who could have been booted out.Some 32 were foreign national offenders who would not be invited back but 31 were “administrative removals”.He said: “I want a very proactive policy of contacting them.“We’re trying to work out what’s the best way to do that now.”And he admitted the number may RISE as officials continue going through the records of deportations that have taken place.Labour backbencher Stephen Doughty last night stormed: “Sajid Javid needs to get an urgent grip on the shambles left for him by the Prime Minister’s policies and cuts. Two Home Secretaries, the Immigration Minister and officials claimed they didn’t know there had been any wrongful deportations.“Last week they claimed there were only a handful – now we find out that it’s at least 63 – and that’s only Windrush cases.”The confession follows weeks spent by Home Office officials suggesting no Windrush-era immigrants had been wrongly deported.The scandal exploded into light last month when Commonwealth leaders slammed Downing Street for refusing them a meeting with Theresa May over the crisis during the Commonwealth Summit.Amber Rudd resigned as Home Secretary after mistakenly telling the Home Affairs Select Committee the Home Office didn’t use immigration removal targets.Mr Javid yesterday said the department was now investigating a potential 4,482 Windrush cases, where citizens needed to be given a permanent leave to remain. So far just 526 have been given the necessary documents. The new Home Secretary also risked a backlash from Theresa May by saying he wouldn’t be using the term “hostile environment” that she adopted in her spell at the Home Office – saying the term hostile was “unBritish”.He separately hinted a new policy paper on post-Brexit immigration could be brought forward to as early as July.Last night Labour’s Shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott demanded justice for the Windrush generation.She blasted: “The hostile environment created by Theresa May has led to illegal deportations of lawful citizens.“Their lives have been potentially destroyed and uprooted because of this Government’s immigration policies.“Apologies and empty words of sympathy are not enough to undo the damage and great pain that has been caused to an entire community.”Home Affairs Select Committee chair Yvette Cooper said there were still many unanswered questions over Windrush.She added: “It is shocking to find that 63 people may have been wrongly removed or deported and troubling that they have not yet been contacted.“It was also significant that the Home Secretary admitted they have no way of knowing either how many Windrush cases may have lost their homes and jobs.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pc prudes ruining the fun
story: A storm over some teacups has led to the sacking of two lifeboat crew members from the RNLI. A senior female member of staff discovered “inappropriate material of a sexual nature” in their station cupboard.That is, she found a pair of novelty tea mugs which featured nude women with the crew members’ heads super-imposed on them.They had swapped them as secret Santa gifts.Four other crew members have resigned in protest at the sackings, locals have started a petition to reinstate the pair and long-term donors have threatened to withdraw funding. But the RNLI insists it has not gone overboard. A statement claims the incident was “not trivial” as the saucy mugs presented a “safeguarding breach”.“Safeguarding” in this context clearly has nothing to do with the physical safety of those at risk of drowning, ostensibly the remit of the RNLI. One of the offenders had 15 years’ experience of saving lives at sea, which he is now forbidden to make use of.Apparently, safeguarding the emotional safety of any potential offence-taker is more important. Similarly, few will be surprised to hear of a humour deficit in academia. But one incident shows that a poorly received joke is no laughing matter.At the annual meeting of the International Studies Association (ISA) in San Francisco, some scholars found themselves in a crowded hotel lift. Simona Sharoni, a professor of women’s and gender studies at Merrimack College in Massachusetts, offered to press the buttons for her colleagues.Richard Ned Lebow, a political scientist at King’s College London, jokingly asked to be let off at the “ladies’ lingerie” department. It was a fairly standard, if old-fashioned, gag. But Sharoni claims that “as a survivor of sexual harassment”, she was “quite shaken by this incident”. Later that day she lodged a formal complaint.Hearing she had done it, Lebow attempted to reach out to her, writing that: “Like you, I am strongly opposed to the exploitation, coercion or humiliation of women.”However, making such a “frivolous” complaint, he argued, risked diverting attention from “the real offences that trouble us both”. By describing the obviously frivolous complaint as frivolous, he aggravated matters further, it seems. Sharoni hit back, saying she “cannot and will not remain silent when misogyny is at play”.She was not alone in confusing a harmless attempt at humour with a hatred for womankind.Last week, the ISA upheld her complaint, ordering Lebow to write an “unequivocal apology” for his “offensive and inappropriate” joke or face disciplinary action.To his credit, he has refused to comply and denounced the ISA’s ruling as a “horrifying and chilling example of political correctness” that “encourages others to censor their remarks for fear of retribution”.No reasonable adult of sound mind, with any experience of real life, could possibly find Lebow’s joke about ladies’ lingerie offensive, let alone misogynistic. But policing of such saucy jokes is more common than you would think.Free Speech University Rankings, recently revealed by online free speech website Spiked, showed some British universities and students’ unions have bans on offensive jokes and banter — usually as part of their policies against sexual harassment.And it is not just jobsworth bosses, snow- flake students and highly strung academics taking offence at harmless banter — as saucy puns can even become a police matter. A butcher in Staffordshire was recently rapped by the police for the innuendo-laden signs outside his shop.Slogans promoting “big-breasted birds”, “big cocks” and offers to “have your rump tenderized” have adorned his boards for ten years. No member of the public felt sufficiently offended to complain to the police in that time.Nevertheless, the local police chief inspector warned the butcher to “give careful consideration” to his slogans, in case anyone takes offence in future. The joyless claims that smutty humour constitutes sexual harassment, a safe- guarding breach or any tangible harm whatsoever, are certainly worthy of ridicule.But when jokes no naughtier than Victorian postcards can see people disciplined and sacked, and innuendos no saucier than a Carry On one-liner draw the attention of the police, we need to get serious about defending smut.Fraser Myers writes for spiked-online, where this article also appears.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: england flag ban russia world cup
story: Mark Roberts, Englands head of football policing, said they could also be seen as antagonistic and imperialistic.The warning comes after Russian yobs attacked England supporters in 2016 and posted snaps of dozens of stolen St Georges flags.England play their first World Cup group game against Tunisia on June 18And Mr Roberts, football policing lead for the National Police Chiefs’ Council,  said : “I think people need to be really careful with flags.“It can come across as imperialistic and cause antagonism.”Meanwhile, Three Lions were warned they face up to FIFTEEN years hard labour in a Russian ‘gulag’ for rioting at the World Cup.The stiff penalties for causing trouble and ticket touting were spelled out by England’s head of football policing.Mark Roberts, deputy chief constable of South Yorkshire Police, also said England fans would face an ‘’avenue of police and military with batons, shields and guns’’ on their way to World Cup games.Mr Roberts revealed that Russian police observers were present when more than 100 England fans were arrested during riots in Amsterdam for the friendly match against Holland in March. He urged Three Lions fans to be on their best behaviour in Russia and warned them what to expect from the host nation, saying : “The style of policing is really different. You will see thousands of police as you approach the stadium.“You will be walking down avenues of police with shields, helmets and guns.”Chief Inspector Joseph Stokoe, of the Met Police and head hooligan spotter in Russia, added : “People need to be aware that the numbers of police and military that you will see at games will frankly be off the scale as to what you see in the UK.”British police say the chances of violence at matches will be “remote.”Football policing boss Mr Roberts said : “Russia is committed to providing a safe haven and a festival of football.“Notwithstanding everything else that is going on, we do have a shared interest in this,” he said in reference to the Salisbury poisoning of Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia, and Boris Johnson’s comparison of Vladimir Putin to Hitler.At a briefing held at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office in Westminster yesterday, Mr Roberts outlined the punishment awaiting hooligans falling foul of local Russian cops.At the minor end of the scale, touts face a £20,000 fine and deportation for every ticket they are caught selling while petty offences are punishable with 15 days imprisonment and a £291 fine.Individual hooligans causing trouble face five years hard labour in a detention centre, 480 hours of community service and a £5,825 fine.Anyone caught and convicted of mass disorder will be sentenced to between eight and 15 years hard labour and 10 years in a modern day gulag for assaulting anyone in authority, such as a cop or soldier.Up to 10,000 England fans are expected to travel to Russia, despite the paltry allocation of official tickets, through the FA.Just 1,460 tickets have been allocated to England for the Tunisia match, 1,772 for the second group game against Panama in Nizhny Novgorod on June 24 and 2,359 for the final encounter four days later against Belgium in Kalinigrad, on the Polish border.Mr Roberts warned that any fans travelling without a ticket for the World Cup would be unlikely to be granted a visa to enter Russia.He also pointed out the logistical problems caused by the “huge distances” between cities and shortage of available accommodation.A total of 1,751 football banning orders have been issued by courts against yobs who must surrender their passports in advance of the tournament.Spotters from the UK Football Policing Unit are being deployed at UK ports to watch for hardcore thugs trying to sneak out of the country and will also be on the ground in Russia to engage with fans.Police chief Mr Roberts said the main concern were middle-of-the road fans who end up drinking too much and causing trouble rather than known hooligans.He said : “They are the people who there with a stag party excess...this gives me a degree of concern.”Warning of the particular concern about offence being caused in Volgograd and at its commemorative sites, he added : “Any student of history will know Russian casualties during World War Two were horrific.“If people from any other country got drunk and placed their flag on the Cenotaph it would make the locals here angry.”Kevin Miles, chief executive of the England Supporters’ Federation, has visited the cities where the Three Lions are playing, and said : “We have to treat the place with respect.“It is one thing to hang a flag up in a bar where the landlord has been taking your money.“But it is quite another to put in a place of particular sensitivity.“We want to be treated as welcome guests.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: twitter to hide troll tweets
story: The new system will deal with “troll-like” behaviour from users who are reported as abusive but don’t go as far as deserving to be banned permanently, bosses said.Clues that someone is a troll are they are without a confirmed email address, they sign up to several Twitter accounts at the same time or they heavily tweet other accounts that do not follow them.Twitter’s Del Harvey said a small number of users are “engaged in behaviours that really distort and detract from the experience that people have”She added: Because this content doesnt violate our policies, it will remain on Twitter, and will be available if you click on Show more replies or choose to see everything in your search setting.The result is that people contributing to the healthy conversation will be more visible in conversations and search. The company said early tests of the system had shown a reduction in the number of abuse reports being filed, indicating users were having a better experience because of the reorganisation.Earlier this year Twitter announced plans to focus on the health of conversation taking place on the platform, with chief executive Jack Dorsey admitting the site had been misused in the past but was committed to help increase the collective health, openness, and civility of public conversation, and to hold ourselves publicly accountable towards progress.Twitter has been regularly criticised for its approach to handling abuse and offensive content, something Mr Dorsey has said it must continue to improve.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: its official a chimps bed is cleaner than a teenagers as they have less dirty bacteria
story: The apes build hygienic tree nests out of fresh branches and leaves each night.And they contain fewer “dirty” bacteria shed by skin than the unchanged sheets of their adolescent human relatives.In fact, the chimps put most people to shame.Researchers collected swabs from 41 nests in Tanzania.They had a much greater variety of bugs than human beds — to be expected in African jungles.But the US study found no more than a handful of fleas and lice.And the nests were far less likely to harbour bacteria left by the occupants’ own bodies than our beds.Team leader Megan Thoemmes said: “We found almost none of those microbes in the chimpanzee nests, which was a little surprising.”About 35 per cent of bacteria in human beds stem from our own bodies.And she added: “We wanted to know how this compares with some of our closest evolutionary relatives, the chimpanzees, which make their own beds daily.”Ms Thoemmes, a PhD student at North Carolina State University, added: “This work really highlights the role that man-made structures play in shaping the ecosystems of our immediate environment.“In some ways, our attempts to create a clean environment for ourselves may actually make our surroundings less ideal.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle tough relationship with dad thomas
story: As Prince Harry took to the airwaves with a pre-recorded talk about mental health, his future father-in-law was in the grip of a very public anxiety attack.Now Thomas Markle, 73, who lives a reclusive life in Mexico, has ruled himself out of the royal wedding once and for all, saying he is having heart surgery.Meghans father had earlier vowed to walk his daughter up the aisle after she begged him to be there - but hes been forced to pull out for a second time.And he says son Tom Jr triggered his heart scare by writing an open letter warning Harry not to marry his daughter this Saturday.Now one of the brides pals has revealed Meghan’s turmoil over the saga.The friend said: “Meghan has had her ups and downs with her dad.What we know so far...“But she thought the past year or so, she and her dad were in a good place. She’s been devastated by what’s happened.“After the revelation he had staged those paparazzi pictures, she has felt so let down and majorly questioned his loyalties.“He collaborated with the Press yet never condemned the actions of his other children Samantha and Junior, who were forever publicly disparaging Meghan.”While history has taught us is that the royals are adept at looking after themselves, this latest episode has left many wondering: just who is looking out for Thomas Markle?Clearly, the retired Hollywood lighting director has been left to fend for himself.Palace sources indicate that he was offered significant help and advice — but he turned it down.They also suggested that Meghan, 36, and Harry, 33, had tried to contact him before she finally got through yesterday.Thomas said he had not heard from his younger daughter after it made global news that he was not going to the wedding.But he said he had changed his mind after Meghan had called him.As for the advice — maybe it was never offered or perhaps he refused it as a proud man who believed he could handle the pressure.Either way, the Palace suits should have stayed in close contact because they must know the pressure is worse than he expected.Now he’s so anxious he’s been “popping Valium for the pain, especially when I hear about my oldest daughter”.That is Samantha Markle — Meghan’s estranged half-sister who hasn’t seen her for ten years and is not invited.She has been shading Meghan as a “pushy princess” at every opportunity.And why no intervention from the Palace?Why has no one flown over to collect him, protect him behind castle gates and show some ­concern for a vulnerable man with heart problems?Where did it all go wrong and who to believe in this sorry saga?Thomas Markle Snr was a successful lighting director, but obviously bad with money.After his retirement he declared himself bankrupt in 2016 with credit card debts of £24,181 and savings of just £160.He moved to tiny Rosarito just across the US border with Mexico, hiding from the world in a ­ramshackle cliff-top house and not socialising with any of the expats.Thomas was so upset after he was pictured earlier this year looking dishevelled, he wanted to control the narrative.He colluded with a photo agency to get shots of him being measured for a suit, working out, reading a book on English history and looking at internet ­pictures of Harry and Meghan.Then came the bombshell revelation that he was so embarrassed to have been rumbled taking cash for the snaps, that he was pulling out of the wedding.Princess Diana’s best friend Rosa Monckton helped her pal dodge the paparazzi — but also knew how she used them for her own ends.Rosa told The Sun: “He strikes me as a man who is out of his depth at every level on this and I don’t judge him at all.“They should have advised him to hide up somewhere until after the wedding. He’s obviously very vulnerable and I don’t know what could have been done or should have been done to offer him more advice and protection.”So should that advice have come from Meghan — the actress with a grasp of the pitfalls of global fameTo answer that you need to understand their up-and-down relationship. Thomas was overjoyed at the birth of his baby girl with second wife Doria Ragland and appears to have been a positive role model for Suits star Meghan.Meghan has credited her dad — who won two Emmys — with being a huge influence on her career.Describing him as “hardworking” and “caring”, she has said that he “invested in my future so that I could grow up to have so much”.For a man from a poor family who grew up on simple dinners of “potatoes and spam”, this was helped by a £500,000 lottery win when Meghan was nine. Her half-brother Tom Jnr said: “That money allowed Meg to go to the best schools and get the best training”.Thomas Snr overcame the racial prejudice of others to marry an African-American and helped develop his daughter’s social conscience.He and Doria got hitched in 1979 but separated when Meghan was six.However, Thomas stayed in close contact with his daughter.Meghan recalled him buying a white Barbie family set and a black Barbie family — splitting them up to make “her” family. But as a teenager she didn’t want to see her father.Driving through her home city of Los Angeles aged 18 with then-best friend Ninaki Priddy, she said she would not visit her dad as they “weren’t on the best of terms”.But a post Meghan sent to her dad on Instagram on Father’s Day 2016 showed the extent of his influence on her and her love for him.She declared: “To this day your hugs are still the very best in the whole wide world. Thanks for my work ethic, my love of Busby Berkeley films and club sandwiches, for teaching me the importance of handwritten thank-you notes, and for giving me that signature Markle nose. I love you xo — Bean.” It was accompanied by a photo showing Meghan as an infant laying on her father’s chest.But a friend said of Thomas: “He’s always been a bit of a slob, selfish with no emotional intelligence.“They didn’t really connect when she was growing up as a girl and didn’t bond when she was a woman.“There were periods when they were closer — he helped her move to Toronto when she started Suits (in 2012). But as he’s become older he’s become much more reclusive.“The man he is today is not the man he was even ten, 15 years ago. He just eats junk food, sleeps in, drinks and reads.“She has helped him many times financially. But there just comes a point when you have to let go.“Not exactly wash her hands of him but there is only so much she can do.“Hence why she didn’t feel Harry had to meet him or that she needed her dad’s approval to get married.”Thomas is now saying he will make the wedding — as long as doctors allow him to fly. Let’s hope for Meghan’s sake he does.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: jagger right about brexit sun says
story: It should decide right now to commit serious resources to leaving with no deal.Theresa May’s “customs partnership” is a dud. It doesn’t free us to be the global trader she wants. The Gaza bloodbath should horrify even Israel’s staunchest supporters.It is hard to argue that shooting live rounds into a crowd is proportionate. But consider the terrifying threat Israel faces. This was not a peaceful demo. Hamas, the terror group sworn to wipe Israel off the map, aims to use it to penetrate the border and kidnap Jews.“We will tear out their hearts,” its leader has said. title: meghan markles family cash in on royal wedding with c4 show meet the markles fronted by chicken shop date host
story: Fronted by Chicken Shop Date host Amelia Dimoldenberg, the hour long programme explored the actress family from her half sister Samantha to her eighth cousin and nephew.Previously, The Sun exclusively revealed in 2017 that Meghans personal life would be explored in a documentary.The programme followed Chicken Shop Date online sensation, Amelia Dimoldenberg travelling to the United States to explore the Royal Wedding frenzy surrounding the upcoming nuptials of Meghan Markle and Prince Harry.In this celebratory one-off documentary, Amelia attempts to get an invitation to the wedding by working her way into the Markle family.Amongst those interviewed in the documentary were Meghans half-sister Samantha - who has reportedly penned a book titled The Diary of Princess Pushy’s Sister - as well as Meghans knife throwing eighth cousin Jeff, and her nephew Tyler who has created a Markle-branded strain of weed called the Markle Sparkle.Bizarrely, Jeff - who is also a family historian - said he has been doing research back to the 15th century which shows Meghan is related to a high sheriff who was from the UK, and is also related to Prince Harry.He also claims that the Markle family are related to H.H. Holmes who owned a hotel in Chicago who created a factory of death to murder the innocents who visited the fair.He was the first serial killer, he claims, adding that he was a pure evil genius.Her half-sister Samantha Markle also spoke of her relationship with the Royal bride and her own relationship with her husband before telling the host her husband is addicted to tabloid stories about Meghan and Samantha, and slammed rumours she was writing a tell-all.Amelia travelled across America to track down significant people from Meghan’s past and met members of her extended family.At its heart, the wedding is a story of two people in love, but the couples union allowed Amelia to explore a wide range of subjects and will ask what the Americans really think of Meghan joining the Royal Family.On her documentary, the host says: “Exploring Meghan Markle’s America was a crazy journey for me. title: meghan markle mum doria ragland airport royal wedding
story: Doria Ragland was seen carrying a Burberry garment bag as she was picked up outside her California home by a black SUV on Tuesday.The 61-year-olds driver could be seen loading a suitcase and holdall into the back before heading to Los Angeles International Airport, where they entered through a private entrance.According to TMZ, the mother-of-the-bride was dropped off at the terminals new private suite - reserved for the rich and famous - and comes with a hefty price tag.Doria, dressed in a black blazer over a white T-shirt and loose-fitting khaki trousers, got the full VIP treatment as she was driven privately across the tarmac straight to her first-class flight.Shes set to stay at Cliveden House in Berkshire, where rooms cost up to £1,500 a night, with Meghan for her last night before she officially joins the royal family.What we know so far...As the yoga instructor made her way to the airport, speculation resurfaced about who would walk Meghan down the aisle after her dad Thomas Markle Snr pulled out of the wedding for a second time.The 73-year-old told TMZ he is due to undergo major surgery later today after suffering a heart attack last week - which hes since blamed on his son Thomas Jnr.He told the entertainment website: “They [doctors] will go in and clear blockage, repair damage and put a stent where it is needed.”Mr Markle reportedly said his ex-wife should walk their daughter down the aisle as she weds Prince Harry at Windsor Castle on Saturday.The latest revelation came just hours after it was reported he wanted to go to the wedding — itself only 24 hours after announcing he would not be there.He said he had changed his mind after Meghan begged him to come, sending him a heartfelt text message saying: I love you.He said of the decision: “I’d like to be part of history. Of course I’d walk her down the aisle.  This is a ­historic moment.“I hate the idea of missing one of the greatest moments in history and walking my daughter down the aisle.”The retired lighting director, who lives in Rosarito, Mexico, said medics had told him his heart was “seriously damaged” after a heart attack a week ago.He blamed his health troubles on an open letter written by his son Thomas Jnr, urging the prince not to marry his half-sister.On Monday, Thomas said he would not attend the Windsor wedding because he did not want to embarrass his daughter or the royals after admitting he was paid for staged paparazzi photos.

title: meghan markle mum doria dad thomas barely speaking royal wedding
story: Yoga instructor Doria Ragland is said to be upset at her ex-husband Thomas Markle for the controversy - and for failing to stop his family from trashing their daughter ahead of her wedding to Prince Harry.Doria, who was today pictured heading to the airport to make her way to the UK for her daughters big day, is now tipped to give Meghan away after Thomas said he had to miss the wedding on Saturday and undergo a heart operation.A source close to the family said Dorias relationship with Thomas had already been put under strain as his family continued to bad-mouth their daughter.What we know so far...Reclusive Thomas was recently pictured leaving potted plants out the front of Dorias LA home in an apparent attempt to make peace.The source told The Sun Online: Thomas and Doria are currently barely speaking to one another. He had told friends that he wanted to come with the peace gesture for an appeasement before the wedding and his daughters big day, but his recent actions have crushed that.The source added: The couple were also at odds with one another because of his other children speaking out so disrespectfully about Meghan in the last year.She had asked him to have them not do so, but little changed.Their meet his future son-in-law and the royal family.Thomas later said that he believed Doria would be a good choice to walk Meghan down the aisle.Yoga instructor Doria, who has already met Prince Harry, is described as a free-spirited clinical therapist who has been by her daughters side for  a number of events.Ladbrokes has since put it at 4/6 odds that Meghans mum Doria will be by her side when she walks down the aisle, while Prince Charles is tipped at 2/1.The Duke of Cambridge has also been tipped to step up to the plate, with 5/1 odds of walking Meghan down the aisle, while there have been a title: john mcafee sec motorcade armed guards
story: McAfee, the creator of the anti-virus software that bears his name, has previously gone on the run having fled authorities investigating a killing in Belize in 2012.Now he claims he has gone underground alongside armed guards due to issues with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).He told The Independent: We are in a five vehicle motorcade. All vehicles driven by ex-military special forces and filled to the brim with heavily-armed security personnel.I purposely and publicly committed a felony this morning to call the SEC out. Im mad as hell and Im not taking any more s*** from corrupt-to-the-core government agencies.McAfee was served with a subpoena by the SEC in 2016, reported to be related to his involvement in cyber-currencies.In a video recently posted on his Twitter account, he declares: The SEC was never intended to have this power, please God America, wake up and see what has happened.The SEC is in charge of our entire industry, our companies, our manufacturing, our distribution, our creativity, our entrepreneurship.When it was created, in the wisdom of the creators, it had only civil powers. If it got p****d off at you, it could sue you, end of story.Now, with the cooperation of the justice department, the SEC can get involved, or bring people in who can punish you beyond a civil suit.The SEC owns America, please God, wake up people. And if you think that an agency of the US government would not stoop to assassination, kidnapping, threats, then what are you smoking?He also shared images appearing to show him wearing body armour alongside members of a security team, as well as an image showing scores of external security cameras in operation.McAfee, who was born in Sling, Gloucestershire, was one of the engineers of California’s Silicon Valley during the 1980s electronics boom.In 1987, he founded his famous McAfee anti-virus software company. Thanks to his policy of giving away the product for free and charging for customer support, it became an instant hit.He sold his stake in 1994, netting around £60million.The money funded an opulent playboy lifestyle which included buying homes in Hawaii, Arizona, Colorado and New Mexico, as well as indulging his hobby of aerotrekking — flying unlicensed microlight aircraft at low altitude.McAfee later moved to Belize where he established a biotechnology research facility, but ran in trouble with local cops.His facility was first raided on the suspicion he was producing methamphetamine, though these charges were quickly dropped.He was then hunted through Central America after a neighbour whom he had argued with was found dead. He then fled, sparking a spectacular international manhunt throughout Central America.Later arrested in Guatemala, he spent a week in a local jail before flying back to the US. Belize cops still insist he is a person of interest in his neighbours death, but he denies any involvement and accuses local authorities of corruption.

title: pakistan man eyes gouged out family marriage
story: Abdul Baqi, 22, from Nasirabad, in the Balochistan region of the country, told his parents on Saturday that he wanted to propose to his girlfriend.But shortly after the meeting, Abdul was attacked by his dad Dost Muhammmad, 70, and his four brothers.The group held down their terrified loved one and gouged out both of his eyes from their sockets with a spoon and cut the veins with a knife.They locked his mother in another room so that she could not intervene and save her son.Abdul, who is being treated in hospital, said his father attacked him three hours after he made the engagement proposal.He said: “I was taken to a room by my father and four brothers where they tied me to a bed and started taking out my eyes.I kept shouting at them what were they doing? But they didnt listen to my pleas.Baqi told how his depraved dad used a spoon to blind him for life.He said: My father used the back of a spoon to take out my first eye. I saw my eye dangling out of the socket.“He then used a knife to cut the veins.When they removed my first eye, I requested them to leave me now but they didnt listen to me at all and removed the other one as well.After they finished, I pleaded to them to please kill me now but they replied they want me be an example for other boys in the village.Abdul was rushed to a government-run hospital in Quetta by his other siblings, who were informed by neighbours about the disturbing assault.He was immediately referred to Karachis Jinnah Post Graduate Medical Centre, where doctors confirmed the 22-year-old will never see again.The brave lad’s father and two brothers have been arrested while police are still hunting his other two siblings.

title: labour want to repeal reams of immigration law including deportation targets landlord checks and bank account freezes diane abbott reveals
story: The Shadow Home Secretary made the announcement as she vowed to end Theresa May’s ‘hostile environment’ policy in the wake of the Windrush scandal.And she said her party would rescind all elements of the legislation used to support the policy, as well as close down two controversial immigration detention centres.It is another signal a Jeremy Corbyn government would water down tough think-tank in London today, also said an incoming Labour administration would shut Yarls Wood in Bedford and Brook House near Gatwick Airport.Both privately-run detention centres have been the subject Secretary Sajid Javid revealed 63 members of the so-called Windrush generation” may have been wrongly removed or deported.Ms Abbott said the scandal surrounding the people who came to the UK from the Commonwealth in the post-war decades was a direct consequence of Mrs Mays policy of making life as difficult as possible for illegal immigrants.She said: Sajid Javid made a promise to make things title: anne frank diary dirty jokes new hidden pages
story: Digital editing techniques have deciphered the writing on two pages of Anne Frank’s diary that she had covered over with brown masking paper, discovering four risque jokes and a candid explanation of sex, contraception and prostitution.“Anyone who reads the passages that have now been discovered will be unable to suppress a smile,” said Frank van Vree, director of the Netherlands Institute for War Holocaust and Genocide Studies.“The ‘dirty’ jokes are classics among growing children. They make it clear that Anne, with all her gifts, was above all also an ordinary girl.”Anne, age 13 at the time, wrote the two pages on September 28, 1942, less than three months after she, her family and another Jewish family went into hiding from the Nazis in a secret annex behind a canal-side house in Amsterdam.Later on, possibly fearing prying eyes or no longer liking what she had written, she covered them over with brown paper, their content remaining a mystery for decades.But its now emerged the pages contained four jokes about sex that Anne herself described as “dirty” and an explanation of women’s sexual development, sex, contraception and prostitution.“They bring us even closer to the girl and the writer Anne Frank,” Ronald Leopold, executive director of the Anne Frank House museum said.Experts on Anne’s diary said the newly discovered text, when studied together with the rest of her diary, reveals more about Anne’s development as a writer than it does about her interest in sex.Leopold said the words are similar to other passages dealing with sex that already have been published in the multimillion-selling diary.However, he said it provides an early example of how Anne “creates a fictional situation that makes it easier for her to address the sensitive topics that she writes about.”In her diary, for example, she addressed entries to a fictional friend named Kitty.Anne wrote her diary while she and her family hid for more than two years during World War II.The family went into hiding in July 1942 and remained there, provided with food and other essentials by a close-knit group of helpers, until August 4 1944, when they were discovered and ultimately deported to Auschwitz.Only Anne’s father Otto Frank survived the war while Anne, at the age of 15, and her sister died in Bergen-Belsen camp.After the war, Otto Frank had his daughter’s diary published, and it went on to become a symbol of hope and resilience that has been translated into dozens of languages, and the house where the Franks hid was turned into a museum that is one of Amsterdam’s most popular tourist attractions.

title: how vodafone was shaped into a behemoth
story: The second Vodafone chief executive, who succeeded Sir Gerry at the end of 1996, was Sir Chris Gent, a prot&#233g&#233 of Sir Ernie Harrison, the East End docker's son who as chairman had taken Racal into telecoms in the first place.His period at the helm is remembered as a period of swashbuckling global expansion, during which Vodafone first moved into the US in a big way with the 1999 acquisition of Airtouch, for $66bn.This was followed a year later by what remains the biggest takeover ever done by a British company - the $183bn acquisition of German mobile operator Mannesmann, which put itself in play after agreeing to buy Orange in the UK, going back on a gentleman's agreement that the two companies had not to encroach on each other's turf.As required by the EU's competition authorities, Vodafone subsequently sold Orange to France Telecom, which today trades under the Orange name.Sir Chris was subsequently criticised for overpaying for Mannesmann, the deal having been done at the height of the bubble in telecoms, media and technology stocks, but his genius was in using Vodafone shares as its acquisition currency rather than cash.That not only meant Vodafone rode out the later downturn in the sector because, unlike some rivals that had used cash to do deals, its balance sheet was not as heavily geared. It also meant the company's by-then prodigious cash-flow - augmented by the sale of unwanted assets - could be invested in upgrading and expanding its networks, rather than having to be spent on servicing debt.Sir Chris's time is also associated with heavy investment in 3G licences around Europe.It was a thrilling time to be covering the company's fortunes and the soundtrack to it all was Bohemian Like You, a track by the US band The Dandy Warhols, which became ubiquitous as Vodafone became one of the world's heaviest-spending advertisers.When Sir Chris stepped down, in 2003, it fell to his Indian-born successor, Arun Sarin, to make all that investment pay off.

title: in the future youll mine cryptocurrency by dancing
story: Talking to Sky News, Agnes Cameron said the future-of-work suggestion was a little joke at the expense of "cryptocurrency bros" who have a habit of claiming to have invented "solutions" for post-automation societies."There's a lot of utopianism around cryptocurrencies at the minute - and some of it for good reason - but in some camps there's this idea that all the world's problems are going to be solved by blockchain," said Ms Cameron."In general, it's good to be wary of the claims people make about these technologies."Blockchains are a really interesting application for some very specific use-cases, but they've also become this crazy buzzword, and you see them getting used in all sorts of useless ways."The dancing is a bit artificial in terms of the network," said Ms Cameron."There's nothing to stop you, for example, just using the arrow keys on your computer (or, better, just writing a script to play the game for you), but if we wanted to create a system of 'artificial scarcity' that really did rely on dancing, then you could use force-meters in the pads or something to ensure someone was actually dancing."This sounds silly, but it's actually not such a wild proposition. All currency systems require some form of scarcity to operate, and with digital currencies that scarcity needs to be imposed artificially: otherwise someone could just declare they owned billions of bitcoin."In mainstream cryptocurrencies that gets tied to an absolute number of total coins, but by tying it to a finite resource - in this case, how much dancing someone can do - you can also propose scarcity limits."Dance Dance Revolution is also a good suit for the potential cryptocurrency as an "automatic oracle," she explained to Sky News.

title: david davis tells theresa customs
story: NewsDavid Davis 'tells Theresa May her customs plan could be ILLEGAL'It is a huge blow for the Prime Minister&nbspShareByAndrew GregoryPolitical EditorNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent10:57, 16 MAY 2018NewsTime is running out to break the customs deadlock (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShareGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May has been dealt a blow over Brexit after being warned her customs plan could be illegal. David Davis has told the Prime Minister that her favoured plan for a customs partnership with the EU could violate international trade law. Lorand Bartels, senior counsel at Linklaters who teaches WTO law at Cambridge University, said: “The customs union partnership model raises a question of WTO legality. It requires businesses to track imported products but not competitive domestic products. That violates one of the WTO’s non-discrimination obligations.”  It comes as Labour is set to stage a Commons ambush in a bid to force the Government to publish secret papers on its plans for a customs deal with Brussels after Brexit .    In the Commons, Labour will use ancient parliamentary rules to force a binding vote which could see ministers having to hand over all the papers presented to the Brexit war Cabinet on the economic effects of both options.  Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer said: “The Government’s Brexit strategy is in complete and utter deadlock. Nearly two years on from the referendum ministers have still yet to agree what our future customs and trading relationship with Europe will look like after Brexit. Instead, the Prime Minister has wasted months pursing her two fatally flawed customs options and presiding over a government that is too busy arguing with itself to negotiate for Britain.” But the de facto deputy Prime Minister insisted that the UK will not be asking for an extension to the almost two-year transition period with the European Union.   Cabinet Office minister David Lidington said the Government wanted to demonstrate that we have thought this through with its Brexit white paper.   He said two ministerial working groups set up by Theresa May last week to look for improvements to customs proposals could take weeks. The PM has asked smaller groups of ministers to go away and test out over the next days and weeks those detailed questions, he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. So, for example, on the new customs partnership the questions are around to what extent does this inhibit an independent trade policy for the future and can we mitigate those impacts? Mr Lidington confirmed that assessments are being made on the legal risks of the customs options being considered.

title: labour demands powers councils seize
story: NewsLabour demands powers for councils to seize tower blocks with dangerous claddingIt comes as Grenfell survivors called on the government to urgently strip flammable cladding from hundreds of tower blocks around the country&nbspShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent10:36, 16 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShareGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour is demanding new powers for councils to seize tower blocks with dangerous cladding ahead of the one-year anniversary of the Grenfell Tower fire next month. They want local authorities to be able to apply to the courts to confiscate any block which is putting lives at risk because of dangerous cladding, and which the owner is refusing to fix. It comes after survivors of the fire which killed 71 people Grenfell Tower last June called on the government to urgently strip flammable cladding from hundreds of tower blocks around the country. The government says it is down to landlords to replace failed cladding but that position is being kept under review.  Legal disputes between freeholders and leaseholders over who should pay mean that lots of blocks remain untouched.     The review of building regulations from Dame Judith Hackitt, which was commissioned by the government in the wake of Grenfell, is expected to report back this week. But there are concerns that Dame Judith won't go far enough.  Labour is calling for a complete overhaul of building safety checks and controls in a debate in Parliament this afternoon.     The Shadow Housing Secretary, John Healey MP, has written to Secretary of State, James Brokenshire setting out Labour’s detailed demands on building safety, including: requiring non-combustible cladding and insulation on high-rise blocks, a ban on ‘desktop studies’, full publication of the ownership and safety status of all tower blocks, clear powers for councils to enforce testing on suspect blocks and a &pound1bn emergency Fire Safety Fund.    In the letter, John Healey MP, Labour’s Shadow Housing Secretary, said:  “More than 11 months on, the time for warm words is long past, and people are rightly asking why so little has changed since the Grenfell Tower fire.   “A series of commitments made by Ministers up to and including the Prime Minister have not been honoured. When Grenfell survivors and worried residents in other tower blocks should have seen action, they have had to suffer painfully slow progress and broken promises.   What was a national disaster is now becoming a national disgrace.   “The forthcoming final report of the Hackitt Review into building regulations and fire safety will be an important chance for the Government to show its commitment to a complete overhaul of the discredited system of building safety checks and controls.  When people’s lives are at risk, the Government’s duty is clear-cut and Government action must be equally clear-cut.”    The full letter from John Healey MP to Housing Secretary, James Brokenshire   Dear James         As we approach the one-year anniversary of the terrible fire at Grenfell Tower, our unwavering commitment remains to ensure Grenfell residents have the help and new homes they need, those responsible are held fully to account, and all necessary steps are taken so that a disaster like this can never happen again.         However, more than 11 months on the time for warm words is long past, and people are rightly asking why so little has changed since 14 June last year.         A series of commitments made by Ministers up to and including the Prime Minister have not been honoured. When Grenfell survivors and worried residents in other tower blocks should have seen action, they have had to suffer painfully slow progress and broken promises. What was a national disaster is now becoming a national disgrace.

story: News'I couldn't trust myself': Man with crippling OCD says disorder convinced him he'd cheated on his girlfriendScott Reeves, 23, said he didn't know who he was after suffering years of mental health problems stemming from meningitis as a baby&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByHannah Robinson11:22, 16 MAY 2018NewsScott Reeves has suffered with obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) since childhood, and wants to help others with the condition (Image: Jerome Ellerby / Hull Daily Mail)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who survived meningitis as a baby says the condition left him with crippling OCD - which has even led him to wrongly think he's cheating on his girlfriend. Scott Reeves, from Hull, has bravely opened up about the condition, which has left him with paranoia and cost him his job and relationship. The 23-year-old revealed that after a night out he has even contacted nightclubs asking for CCTV, to prove to himself he didn't do anything he shouldn't have. Scott originally suffered with number OCD at the age of 12, causing him to obsessively count items around him, and went on to more severe versions of paranoia.  He told the Hull Daily Mail : “I have OCD and depression which stem from surviving bacterial meningitis as a baby and also events in my past, and I’m crippling myself because I can’t trust what I have or haven’t done.   “It has already cost me so much with my girlfriend because I can’t get out of my head that I’ve done something wrong or cheated on her. “It would get to the point where I could constantly ring up venues after a night out to look at their CCTV because I couldn’t trust myself, and I even recorded myself at home when I was having a drink because I didn’t trust that I hadn’t left the house. “I ended the relationship for a month because I felt like I was being a bad boyfriend, and even when I went out with my girlfriend I was constantly making notes on my phone whenever she left my side to make sure I wasn’t doing anything wrong. “I completely stopped drinking and even while sober I couldn’t trust that I hadn’t done something wrong. “I ended up in hospital because I was crying all the time over something I had never done, and ended up self-harming because I didn’t know who I was.” Mr Reeves says he has spent many years as an outpatient in Hull’s mental health facilities, due to factors causing issues with his mental health throughout childhood. But now he wants to change his life around so others can see that there is a way of defeating OCD.

story: NewsMeghan Markle's dad 'will NOT attend royal wedding because of major heart surgery' - as mum flies out to London in styleThomas Markle Snr is reportedly due to undergo an operation today, just three days before Meghan ties the knot with Prince Harry&nbspShare&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans22:15, 15 MAY 2018Updated01:20, 16 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle's dad will not attend his daughter's wedding nor walk her down the aisle because of major heart surgery, it has been reported. Thomas Markle Snr says he is due to undergo an operation this morning, just three days before Meghan ties the knot with Prince Harry. He told TMZ details of the surgery, saying: They [doctors] will go in and clear blockage, repair damage and put a stent where it is needed. It comes after Mr Markle Snr reportedly revealed that he wanted to walk Meghan, 36, down the aisle at Windsor Castle, Berkshire, on Saturday.  The 73-year-old was said to have had a 'change of mind' - less than 24 hours after pulling out of performing the honour at St George's Chapel. He earlier told the gossip site: I hate the idea of missing one of the greatest moments in history and walking my daughter down the aisle. But he feared his heart problems could prevent him from doing this.  It is thought Meghan's mum Doria Ragland has stepped in to walk her down the aisle in her father's absence. Earlier on Tuesday, the 61-year-old was picked up from her LA home and chauffeur driven to LAX airport, according to TMZ. The website reports that she was given the A-list treatment, dropped off at the new Private Suite before being driven directly to her flight. The father was said to be back in hospital, undergoing a series of tests, after suffering from serious chest pains following a heart attack last week.  Speaking to Australian news programme Sunrise, Samantha Markle, Meghan's half sister, said: Everything about him being under an incredible amount of stress is true and he, you know, sent me a message that he was undergoing heart surgery so all of that was true. He's been under a tremendous amount of stress amidst challenges and I hope, I think we're all hoping he pulls through this now and can still go the wedding.  The surgery is said to be taking place at 7.30am local time. Mr Markle Snr will likely be recovering from the procedure when his former actress daughter, 36, and Harry, 33, tie the knot in Windsor this weekend. In a statement earlier this month, Kensington Palace said the father, who lives near Rosarito, Mexico, would walk Meghan down the aisle of St George's Chapel. A spokesman said at the time: “Prince Harry and Ms Markle are very much looking forward to welcoming Ms Markle's parents to Windsor for the wedding. Mr Thomas Markle and Ms Doria Ragland will be arriving in the UK in the week of the wedding, allowing time for Prince Harry's family, including The Queen, The Duke of Edinburgh, The Prince of Wales, The Duchess of Cornwall, and The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, to spend time with them before the big day.  Both of the bride's parents will have important roles in the wedding. On the morning of the wedding, Ms Ragland will travel with Ms Markle by car to Windsor Castle. Mr Markle will walk his daughter down the aisle of St George's Chapel. Ms. Markle is delighted to have her parents by her side on this important and happy occasion.” But last night, it was claimed that Mr Markle Snr no longer planned to travel to Britain to give Meghan away after he admitted staging photos for the paparazzi. The father earlier told TMZ that he had meant no harm to his daughter or the Royal Family when he set up a photoshoot in an Internet cafe. The shoot is said to have been part of a deal worth &pound100,000.  Reports suggested some wedding plans had been thrown into turmoil with the ex-Hollywood lighting director deciding to stay put at home. It was claimed Harry was blaming himself for the situation, while Meghan was said to be distraught and standing by her father. Last night, the couple released a statement addressing the reports that Mr Markle Snr was not going to attend the ceremony. A spokesman for Kensington Palace said: This is a deeply personal moment for Ms Markle in the days before her wedding. She and Prince Harry ask again for understanding and respect to be extended to Mr Markle in this difficult situation.

story: NewsRoyal wedding: Homeless near Windsor Castle have sleeping bags taken away by police before Meghan Markle and Harry's big dayWindsor is in lockdown with a heavy police presence and anti-terror bollards are going up in the Berkshire town&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByChris kitching08:22, 16 MAY 2018Updated08:34, 16 MAY 2018NewsA homeless person in a sleeping bag on a pavement in Windsor, Berkshire (Image: Stan Kujawa)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRough sleepers near Windsor Castle have had their sleeping bags and other belongings removed just days before Prince Harry and Meghan Markle tie the knot. The couple are due to wed at St George's Chapel on Saturday, with about 100,000 of well-wishers expected in the Berkshire town and police on high alert. A number of homeless people living near the Queen's residence had their belongings cleared, but police say the rough sleepers they gave them up voluntarily under a scheme overseen by a local charity. As the royal wedding draws near, the area around Windsor Castle is on lockdown and anti-terror bollards are going up as extra police patrol the town.  Thames Valley Police said the sleeping bags and other belongings, including bedding and books, are being stored by the Windsor Homeless Project and will be returned to the rough sleepers after Saturday's nuptials. Tory council leader Simon Dudley had sparked anger months ago after asking police to remove rough sleepers from the affluent borough before the royal wedding. He complained about rough sleepers on Twitter while he was on a Christmas skiing holiday, and then wrote a letter to the police - copying in Prime Minister Theresa May and then-Home Secretary Amber Rudd after he returned to the UK.    Footage obtained by MailOnline shows two homeless men, who were camped outside a Barclays bank across from the castle, putting their possessions in clear plastic bags. The bags were sealed and taken away in a police van. One of the rough sleepers said: There was big speak on the TV about the homeless being helped but when they said helped they meant removed. But a police spokesman insisted that the rough sleepers voluntarily gave up their possessions and they were not forcibly taken away as part of security measures.  He said the possessions will be returned after Windsor hosts the wedding, and officers were just assisting the Windsor Homeless Project with the scheme. Officers will be carrying out security sweeps and screening the thousands of well-wishers who will cram pavements around the castle, hoping to catch a glimpse of Harry and Meghan. But the police spokesman warned that large items deemed to be a security risk will likely be removed by officers. The spokesman said: “Thames Valley Police is working closely with The Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead council, The Windsor Homeless Project, and local support services in order to offer support to homeless people in Windsor.
